title: RUBIK: A Structured Benchmark for Image Matching across Geometric Challenges
author: Thibaut Loiseau (LIGM, Ecole des Ponts, Universite Gustave Eiffel, CNRS, France), Guillaume Bourmaud (Laboratoire IMS, Universite de Bordeaux, France), ...
background: The paper presents a framework to systematically evaluate camera pose estimation methods using image pairs categorized by three geometric difficulty criteria.
contribution: This paper introduces the RUBIK benchmark to solve the lack of structured evaluations in camera pose estimation, achieving a comprehensive assessment of fourteen different methods under varying geometric challenges.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous benchmarks lacked controlled geometric variations, leading to challenges in assessing method robustness across varying difficulty levels.
technical_comparison.novelty: RUBIK systematically organizes 16.5K image pairs based on overlap, scale ratio, and viewpoint angle into 33 difficulty levels.

key_innovation: Utilizes dense co-visibility maps and geometric criteria to quantify challenges in camera pose estimation, offering a meaningful benchmark that highlights method shortcomings.
real_world_impact: The benchmark aims to improve the development of more robust pose estimation techniques, which can have significant implications for augmented reality, robotics, and navigation systems.
limitations: The paper acknowledges potential limitations in co-visibility map robustness due to instance changes between images.

new_terms.co-visibility maps: **Co-visibility maps** are representations that indicate which parts of a scene are visible from multiple camera viewpoints, critical for understanding camera positioning in 3D space.
